content.text: The most common quantified statements in English use words like 'all', 'every', 'each', 'some', 'a', and 'any'. Learning to translate these correctly is the core skill of quantificational logic.

content.definition: Statements with 'all', 'every', 'each', 'any' typically use ∀ with a conditional (→). For example, 'All birds fly' becomes ∀x(Bird(x) → Flies(x)).

content.title: Translating 'All'
content.note: Notice the pattern: 'All A are B' becomes ∀x(A(x) → B(x)). We use an implication because we're saying: IF something is an A, THEN it is a B.

content.definition: Statements with 'some', 'a', 'there is' typically use ∃ with a conjunction (∧). For example, 'Some birds fly' becomes ∃x(Bird(x) ∧ Flies(x)).

content.title: Translating 'Some'
premises: There is a happy cat → ∃x(Cat(x) ∧ Happy(x))
content.note: Notice: 'Some A are B' becomes ∃x(A(x) ∧ B(x)). We use conjunction because we're saying there exists something that is BOTH an A AND a B.

content.text: **Critical distinction**: Universal uses →, existential uses ∧. This is one of the most common mistakes in quantificational logic! Think about why: 'All cats are animals' doesn't say anything about non-cats, so we use implication. But 'Some cat is sleeping' asserts the existence of something that is both a cat AND sleeping.

content.question: How do you translate 'Some dogs bark'?
content.explanation: 'Some dogs bark' is an existential claim: there exists at least one thing that is both a dog AND barks. We use ∃ with ∧ (conjunction), not →.
